rules.rationale: Safety-first precaution: avoid retinoids during pregnancy. Systemic vitamin A derivatives are known to be harmful in pregnancy; topical data are limited, so conservative guidance avoids retinoids.

templates.text_en: To keep this safety-first, can you tell me your pregnancy status (pregnant / trying to conceive / not pregnant / unsure)? Some ingredients are best avoided during pregnancy as a precaution.

As a precaution, avoid retinoids during pregnancy. If you want help with acne or discoloration, options often discussed include azelaic acid and a gentle routine plus daily sunscreen. If youre under clinician care, follow their plan.
If youre trying to conceive, many clinicians recommend avoiding retinoids as a precaution. We can build a gentler plan and discuss alternatives.

During pregnancy, avoid hydroquinone as a precaution because absorption can be higher and data are limited. Consider non-hydroquinone brightening options and strict sunscreen instead, and consult a clinician if you need stronger treatment.
If youre pregnant, be cautious with high-strength leave-on acids or professional peels. If you use acids at all, keep it gentle and low-frequency, and stop if stinging/peeling worsens.

Pregnancy guidance for salicylic acid depends on strength and product type. As a safety-first default, avoid high-strength leave-on/peels and keep to lower-strength or rinse-off options if your clinician agrees.
If youre breastfeeding, avoid applying strong actives on the nipple/areola area and prevent infant skin contact. For prescription products, its best to confirm with your clinician.
If youre taking oral isotretinoin, your skin can become very dry and sensitive. Avoid stacking strong exfoliants and retinoids, keep the routine gentle, and follow your prescribers guidance.
To keep this safe, how old are you (or the person youre asking for)? For minors, we typically keep routines gentle and avoid strong leave-on actives unless a clinician recommends them.

If your skin barrier feels compromised (stinging, burning, peeling), pause exfoliating acids and retinoids, focus on gentle cleansing and barrier repair, and reintroduce actives slowly only after your skin calms down.
If youre sensitive or have a contact allergy history, prioritize fragrance-free products. Fragrance and essential oils are common triggers for irritation or allergy.
To evaluate a specific product, please paste a product link (or the exact brand + product name) and, if possible, the full ingredient list.
When traveling with higher UV exposure, prioritize broad-spectrum sunscreen, reapply regularly, and consider protective clothing. Actives like retinoids/acids can increase irritation in strong sun.
Because this sounds like a high-strength leave-on product, Ill be more conservative: start 12 nights/week, avoid combining with other strong actives, and stop if irritation escalates.
Are you currently using any prescription acne or skin medications (for example, isotretinoin, tretinoin, adapalene)? This affects whats safe to combine.
If youre sunburned, keep things simple: gentle cleanser, bland moisturizer, and sun protection. Avoid exfoliating acids and retinoids until the skin is calm.
After a procedure (laser/peel/microneedling), follow the clinicians aftercare plan. As a general safety measure, avoid strong actives until the skin has recovered.

During breastfeeding, topical retinoids are generally approached with caution. Avoid applying on areas that may contact the infant, and consider confirming with your clinicianespecially for prescription retinoids.
If pregnancy status is unknown, I cant safely recommend retinoids. Please confirm whether youre pregnant or trying to conceive, and well choose a safer plan if needed.
If you have any medical conditions, are pregnant/breastfeeding, or are on prescription treatments, its safest to check with a clinician before starting stronger actives.
Avoid applying strong exfoliants and retinoids directly on the eyelids. If you want to target the eye area, choose a product formulated for it and patch-test.
Use broad-spectrum sunscreen daily, especially when using exfoliants or retinoids. Reapply when outdoors.
If you react to fragrance, look for 'fragrance-free' and check the label for fragrance allergens such as limonene, linalool, citral, and others.
For travel, a minimal kit is often safest: gentle cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen, and one targeted treatment you already tolerate.
